transcriptText:
Pivoting 180 degrees changes the direction of a heart shaped swing, and adds a new layer to your skills.

Involving the lower body is a fun way to add complexity and new challenges to Indian clubs.

Remember to practice moving forward AND backward!

Once you understand the timing behind the step turn pivot, you can do this with 2 clubs.

A variation of this pivot would be twisting your body 180 degrees around itself on the spot instead of stepping.

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

swing with a pivoting turn start with an inner swing as the club circles past the back step and turn 180 degrees in the direction of the momentum you are now swinging in the opposite direction you can step and turn off the front or the back foot you can take multiple steps in either direction explore all the possibilities keep the knees soft and pivot on your toes this time start with an outer swing always practice on both sides you
rawContent:
![Thumbnail (1920x1080)](https://i.ytimg.com/vi_webp/9ogvhTCyKm0/maxresdefault.webp?v=604a19c7)
# [Indian clubs 102 Lesson 9/20 | Swing with a pivoting step turn, with a single club](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9ogvhTCyKm0)

**Visibility**: Public
**Uploaded by**: [Heroic Sport - Indian clubs workouts](http://www.youtube.com/@HeroicSport)
**Uploaded at**: 2021-03-19T01:00:29-07:00
**Published at**: 2021-03-19T01:00:29-07:00
**Length**: 01:50
**Views**: 1244
**Likes**: 42
**Category**: Sports

## Description

```
Pivoting 180 degrees changes the direction of a heart shaped swing, and adds a new layer to your skills.
Involving the lower body is a fun way to add complexity and new challenges to Indian clubs.
Remember to practice moving forward AND backward!

Once you understand the timing behind the step turn pivot, you can do this with 2 clubs.
A variation of this pivot would be twisting your body 180 degrees around itself on the spot instead of stepping.

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS
〄 PHYSICAL ASPECTS
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)
〄 MENTAL ASPECTS
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ and the Pahlavandle™XL to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
```

## Transcript

swing with a pivoting turn start with an inner swing as the club circles past the back step and turn 180 degrees in the direction of the momentum you are now swinging in the opposite direction you can step and turn off the front or the back foot you can take multiple steps in either direction explore all the possibilities keep the knees soft and pivot on your toes this time start with an outer swing always practice on both sides you


## Endscreen
    
- [13 min workout with 1 kettlebell & 1 Indian club/ mudgar/ clubbell](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I2rReMnTKh4)
